titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Christian Conference of Asia Records

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Friday April 12, 2019 at 22:00

did.abstract: These are the official archives of the Christian Conference of Asia, a regional ecumenical organization representing church councils and denominations in Australia, Bangladesh, Burma, Cambodia, East Timor, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Laos, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Sri Lanka, Taiwan and Thailand. The CCA began as the East Asia Christian Conference in 1957 and changed its name to Christian Conference of Asia in 1973.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Christian Conference of Asia

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open to qualified researchers.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Christian Conference of Asia Records (RG 237), Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library.

chronitem.event: At the International Missionary Council meeting at Whitby, East Asian delegates suggested a conference to plan for an Asian office.
Eastern Asia Christian Conference held in Bangkok.
Rajah B. Manikam appointed as Joint Secretary for East Asia for the International Missionary Council (IMC) and World Council of Churches (WCC).
Asia Council on Ecumenical Mission (ACEM) formed.
IMC, WCC, and ACEM came together at Prapat, Indonesia for constituting assembly of the East Asia Christian Conference "The Common Evangelistic Task of the Churches in East Asia."
2nd General Assembly of East Asia Christian Conference (EACC) held at Kuala Lumpur - "Witnessing Together."
Dr. D. T. Niles served as General Secretary.
3rd General Assembly of EACC held in Bangkok - "The Christian Community within the Human Community"
4th General Assembly of EACC held in Bangkok - "In Christ All Things Hold Together."
Mr. U Kyaw Than served as General Secretary.
5th General Assembly held in Singapore - "Christian Action in the Asian Struggle." Name of organization changed to Christian Conference of Asia (CCA).
Rt. Rev. Dr. Yap Kim Hao served as General Secretary.
Asia Sunday instituted. Singapore office opened.
First Asian Ecumenical Center event held, later known as Asia Ecumenical Course.
6th General Assembly held in Penang - "Jesus Christ in Asian Suffering and Hope."
7th General Assembly held in Bangalore - "Living with Christ in People."
Ecumenical Council on Third World Tourism set up.
8th General Assembly held in Seoul - "Jesus Christ Sets Free to Serve." Indonesian churches withdraw from active participation in CCA.
Rev. Dr. Park Sang Jung served as General Secretary.
CCA expelled from Singapore.
CCA staff dispersed to Osaka, Hong Kong, Manila, and Chiang Mai.
Asian Mission Conference, Indonesia.
9th General Assembly held in Manila - "Christ Our Peace: Building a Just Society." Indonesian churches re-activate CCA membership.
Rt. Rev. John Samuel served as General Secretary.
Land purchased in Hong Kong for new CCA center
CCA Center at Shatin dedicated. Conferences held: Asian Students and Youth Gathering, Asian Church Leaders' Conference on Migrant Workers, Refugees, Internally Displace Communities in Asia (MRIA)
Asian Mission Conference, Korea
10th General Assembly held in Colombo - "Hope in God in a Changing Asia." Proposal towards new thrust and new structures. Asian Church Leaders' Conference on Indochina.
Rev. Dr. Toshitsugu Arai served as Acting General Secretary.
Dr. Feliciano V. Carino served as General Secretary.
Joint effort with Federation of Asian Bishops' Conferences (FABC): Asian Movement for Christian Unity (AMCU). First CCA program in China (Youth).
Formation of Congress of Asian Theologians.
11th General Assembly held in Tomohon - "Time of Fullness of Life for All"
Dr. Ahn Jae Woong served as General Secretary.
12th General Assembly held in Chiang Mai - "Building Communities of Peace for All."
Dr. Prawate Khidard served as General Secretary.
CCA office moved from Hong Kong to Chiang Mai.
13th General Assembly held in Kuala Lumpur - "Called to Prophesy, Reconcile and Heal."
Rev. Dr. Henriette Hutabarat Lebang served as General Secretary.
14th General Assembly held in Jakarta.
Mathews George Chunakara appointed General Secretary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection provides extensive valuable documentation of the development of ecumenical Christianity in Asia from the mid-20th century through the early 2000s. The East Asia Christian Conference, formed in 1957 and renamed Christian Conference of Asia in 1973, grew out of earlier efforts of the International Missionary Council and World Council of Churches to support and encourage the development of Christian churches and Asian Christian leaders in Asia. From its foundation, the Christian Conference of Asia has focused on mission, leadership development, ecumenical relationships, and issues of social justice in Asia.

The records are valuable for their documentation of the organizational development of ecumenical Christianity in Asia but also for the insight they provide on a wide variety of social issues in Asia such as development, health, refugees, disabilities, gender, globalization, labor, and other social justice issues. Because CCA networked with so many other religious organizations in Asia and throughout the world, this collection provides valuable insight on the worldwide ecumenical movement throughout the last half of the 20th century.

A large and complex archive, the records in this collection migrated with the CCA throughout Asia as the organization had its headquarters in various countries. The offices and program desks of the CCA were somewhat decentralized and often kept parallel records so there is some overlap and duplication in the archival record. Some records had been compiled and described by the organization in previous years while other similar records were completely unorganized. An effort has been made to rationalize the structure of the archives according to CCA's various leaders, program units, and functions, but it is recommended that the researcher use keyword searching of the finding aid to locate all materials related to any particular event,issue, or person.

Note that many pamphlets and books published by the Christian Conference in Asia are in the Yale Divinity Library's cataloged collection rather than in this archival collection. A search for Christian Conference in Asia as "Publisher" in Orbis results in nearly 200 hits.

For additional description of the history and program activities of the CCA, see From Prapat to Colombo : history of the Christian Conference of Asia (1957-1995) by Yap Kim Hao, and other works in the Library's cataloged collection. The website of the CCA also provides historical information about the organization and a valuable listing of its leaders and staff members over the years: http://cca.org.hk/home/cca-history/.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains files of the CCA General Secretaries and Associate General Secretaries of Finance and Program Coordination. It is predominately composed of correspondence with member councils and churches as well as correspondence with partner and donor agencies. It also contains conference papers, sermons, articles, speeches, and manuscripts from various secretaries and CCA Executive Committee meeting materials. Meeting and conference records include invitations, participant correspondence, planning materials, press releases, programmes, and travel reports. This series also includes early EACC papers and D. T. Niles correspondence and papers. There is considerable overlap between these files and files found in other series. For additional D.T. Niles Papers, see the Divinity Library's record group no. 260.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series documents the work of the CCA Development and Service Desk, which became part of Justice International Affairs, Development and Service upon CCA restructuring in 2000. It is predominately composed of correspondence, collected material, country files, and conference and consultation materials. The series comprises correspondence of the secretary of Development and Service with ecumenical and aid organizations as well as correspondence regarding development issues, emergencies, health and hunger concerns, and refugees. Collected materials contain legal resources, news clippings, reference materials, and reports. Country files comprise papers and research materials as well as country profiles, correspondence, and project reports. Programme materials include Development Fund projects and proposals. The series also contains materials relating to Indochina concerns and Vietnam-Laos-Cambodia (VLC) project materials. Conferences and consultation topics include disabilities, gender and development, health and HIV/AIDS concerns, and third world tourism, and contain conference papers, minutes, participant information, and planning and training materials from meetings and workshops.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series documents the work of Urban Rural Mission, which became part of Faith, Mission, and Unity upon CCA restructuring in 2000. It is predominately composed of administrative files and staff records, correspondence, collected material, country files, and conference and consultation materials. Administrative files include partner agency correspondence and reports, Urban Rural Mission secretary correspondence, financial reports and statements. Country files contain correspondence collected material, country profiles. This series also contains URM-funded project reports and funding proposals. Conferences and consultation topics include globalization, industry, labor, and social justice. This sub-series contains conference papers, meeting minutes, participant invitations and correspondence, programs, as well as general planning materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is primarily composed of administrative records, conference and consultation materials, correspondence, and materials relating to both the Rural Youth Program (RYP) and World Youth Program (WYP). Administrative records contain general correspondence as well as correspondence from the Youth Secretary in addition to materials from partner agencies with project reports and correspondence. Conference and consultation records contain correspondence, program and lecture papers, project proposals, publicity materials, and travel schedules and expenses related to Youth Assembly and Youth Forums. The CCA Youth Committee files contain reports and meeting minutes, and country files comprise correspondence, papers, and project reports. This series also contains papers and correspondence from Youth conferences on the topics of leadership and social concerns and contain conference papers, minutes, and reports, planning materials, and travel arrangements as well as numerous Youth conference delegate and steward applications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is predominately composed of financial reports, correspondence, donors and grants, and materials relating to the purchase and renovation of the Lutheran Theological Seminary in Hong Kong. Financial reports include auditor reports, budgets, and programme income and expenditure reports. This series also includes Finance Committee papers, including correspondence and programme summaries with budget planning materials. Donor and grant materials contain correspondence and agreements with donor agencies, including ICCO and UN-ESCAP, Bread for the World, and others. Materials relating to the purchase and renovation of the Lutheran Theological Seminary include official documents and correspondence, funding requests, building renovation plans, diagrams and photographs, a structural survey report, and costs.
